div.p: The CSÆB is a federated search Portal for Byzantine seals, providing access to all collections encoded using the SigiDoc data model through a single unified interface. Rather than merging everything into one large corpus, the Portal allows individual collections to remain autonomous while being interoperable through the shared encoding standard. To support this approach, the DigiByzSeal team developed an infrastructure based on GitHub repositories:

ul.li: A central SigiDoc repository hosts core materials such as schema, templates, and stylesheets. These files are centrally maintained and are not intended to be modified by individual projects.

Forkable components, including selected code files and authority lists (standardised names and references), are made available for local adaptation. Projects can propose improvements via pull requests to the central repository.
Individual teams (e.g., those in Cologne and Paris) have established their own GitHub organisations, where they manage their EFES-SigiDoc instances and collections of seal editions (in XML format).

div.p: Each seal collection is published as XML files, which are integrated into EFES—a platform for individual SigiDoc XML-based projects. The federated Portal tracks public Git repositories using webhooks. When a new seal is added, the webhook initiates a process that:

ul.li: Pulls the new XML file from the repository
Indexes the file on the EFES-based Portal
Makes it available in the search interface

div.p: This system supports decentralised editing while enabling centralised discovery and search capabilities. Importantly, the federated Portal does not require projects to use EFES specifically. Even raw XML files hosted publicly on Git platforms can be harvested and indexed. The broader aim is to build a collaborative digital infrastructure for sigillography, empowering museums, researchers, and institutions around the world to contribute independently while remaining interconnected.

Are you a researcher working on the publication of Byzantine seals? A private collector in possession of valuable and unique pieces that remain largely unknown to the scholarly community? An institution that already maintains a catalogue of seals, but wants to make them more visible?
Then CSÆB is likely for you.
div.h4: What are the benefits of participating?
div.p: Your seals and your scholarly work will become more visible and findable, reaching a wider academic audience.
This increased accessibility does not come at the cost of your rights. Your authorship and contributions—whether personal or institutional—will always remain clearly credited and protected.
By joining CSÆB, you contribute to a critical mass of searchable seals, enabling multicorpus-based research that can enhance your own work and that of others.

The minimum requirement is to be keen to prepare your sigillographic editions in accordance with the SigiDoc data model: the adoption of the latter will create the common underlying foundation necessary for sigillographic data to be simultaneously queried by the Portal. To do that, you have several options:

ul.li: Host your own collection using an instance such as EFES, which can be accessed in parallel via the Portal.
Manage your collection's metadata in a Git repository, which the Portal will retrieve and index.
Use a web-based input form to describe individual seals according to the SigiDoc data model, making them searchable through the Portal.

div.p: The Portal does not replace independent presentations or institutional publications. Rather, it enhances the visibility of your collections through an additional platform.
The Portal is not a single curated collection. It is a community-driven initiative. Please note that datasets contributed by different partners may vary in depth and descriptive detail.
